text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm live tart flambe that's right do
not be misled by that misleading name
this is really closer to a pizza than a
tart and we are definitely not going to
set it on fire at least not on purpose
and speaking of names you wouldn't know
it by looking but apparently this
Alsatian sensation is actually a german
invention so I'm not exactly sure why
they went with the French name all I can
think is that maybe the German one had
too many consonants but regardless this
is very simple to put together great for
entertaining groups and incredibly
delicious so let's go ahead get started
with the first of four very simple
components and that would be the bacon
so what I have here is 12 ounces of
sliced up bacon that we're going to set
over medium-high heat and we're going to
cook this stirring occasionally but not
all the way okay all we're trying to do
here is render out most of that fat and
while we do want the bacon cooked we
don't want it crisp so all we're going
to do is continue cooking until we have
something that looks like this okay like
I said a lot of that fat is going to
render out but the bacon is not starting
to crisp up yet so that's looking
perfect right there and what we can do
at this point is remove it from the heat
and transfer that into a strainer set
over a bowl because having some rendered
bacon fat around is never a bad thing
plus we don't want our tart flambe over
saturated with grease so we'll go ahead
and let that drain and cool down of
course oh by the way in case you didn't
know any bacon you accidentally drop on
the table you get to eat oh yeah that's
the rule besides it's never a bad idea
to taste some for quality control
purposes but anyway once our bacon is
set we can move on to the second
component this sliced onions and the
reason we're doing these after the bacon
is because we're going to use that same
pan so let's place that back on medium
heat and add in one thinly sliced onion
along with a fairly generous pinch of
salt and there's probably going to be
enough bacon fat attached to the pan for
this step but if it seems too dry you
can go ahead and throw in a spoon of our
rendered fat that's just you cooking and
all we're going to do here is cook these
onions very briefly until they just lose
their rigidity and start to soften up a
little okay so just like the bacon we're
giving these a little bit of a head
start and of course because we added
some salt that's going to draw moisture
out of the onions which is going to
deglaze any of that goodness off the
bottom of the pan and as I mentioned
we're only going to cook these until
they start to
soften up okay the biggest mistake
people make with this recipe is using
caramelized onions which in my opinion
are way too soft and sweet for this
recipe so I'm recommending we cook these
until they just lose that Raj and
they're going to start to look a little
bit wet so for me that's perfect right
there okay as soon as our onions get to
this point we're going to stop we're
going to turn off the heat and we are
simply going to let those cool down to
room temp okay so our onions are set our
bacon set and we can move on to an
equally easy component the cheese
mixture which is going to start with
this for Maj Blanc oh yeah I'm going to
make you go to the fancy grocery store
to find some fromage blanc or I guess
you can make your own since we do have a
video for that which by the way fun fact
I believe was our first viral video but
anyway if you're not familiar for Maj
Blanc is an extra delicious extra tangy
French style cream cheese and then to
that we're also going to add some creme
fraiche another thing you can make
homemade with one of our videos so I'm
going to go ahead and add some creme
fraiche and please note how very
carefully I'm measuring that and then
besides our dairy we will also season
this up with some freshly grated nutmeg
and I'm not sure if I've mentioned
before but it much prefer the freshly
grated to the pre ground it's basically
like the difference between listening to
the Rolling Stones and just an actual
rolling stone so we'll do a little touch
of nutmeg followed by a nice big pinch
of salt as well as some very traditional
freshly ground black pepper and then
last but not least a very untraditional
shake of cayenne pepper hey I'm sure it
would have been very traditional if they
had it around and believe it or not
that's it for our cheese spread so we'll
go ahead and take a spoon and mix that
up and it's probably obvious but let me
mention it anyway you can certainly add
other possibly stinkier cheese's to this
mixture I've had these with monster and
greyer and they're very delicious so if
you wanted to funk this up a little bit
by using one of those feel free you are
after all the Bruno Mars of which cheese
stars but anyway like I said we will
give that a mix and simply set that
aside while we finish our last component
the tower crust and for that we're going
to need about a 5 ounce ball of pizza
dough which conveniently is exactly
one-quarter of our wolfgang puck pizza
dough recipe so we'll go ahead and whip
up a batch of that and we'll place 1/4
of that down on a well floured surface
and then using our hands and a rolling
pin
and of course enough flour to keep it
from sticking what we want to do is roll
that out very thin to about a 10 or 12
inch circle and I mean thin like less
than an eighth of an inch okay having a
thin crispy crust is key here then yes
in case you're wondering because we made
you slice onions and bacon you are
allowed to buy that bag of pre-made
pizza dough at the store but anyway
we're going to roll that out nice and
thin as shown at which point we're going
to transfer that into our cold cast-iron
pan and to make that move a little
easier what we'll do is roll our dough
over our pin like this
whoops actually like this and that's
going to allow us to transfer it into
the pan without it getting all messed up
like that well we tried so let's go
ahead and straight that out and then
what we'll do at this point is transfer
that on a medium high heat because what
we're going to do is pre cook the bottom
of this crust so we're going to place
that on medium high heat and it's going
to take a few minutes to come up to temp
and as it does you're going to see
little bubbles forming which I'm going
to recommend we poke with a fork okay so
those are little ones but eventually
you'll see bigger ones and maybe even
the occasional giant one and the reason
we'll pop those is because this isn't a
pizza we don't want something bubbly and
chewy we want something thin and kind of
crispy so that is the thought process
behind the D bubbling and what we're
going to do is keep cooking that on
medium high until our bottom is nicely
browned so let's flip that over and take
a look okay you see that that is perfect
right there it is just about to start
getting charred so at that point we can
go ahead and pull it off the heat and
proceed to top it with our other three
components so first up we will spread
over a very generous application of our
cheese mixture and don't be shy we want
a good amount of this stuff and by the
way the reason for the pre cooking of
the crust and the onions and the bacon
for that matter is because we need to
successfully accomplish this in a home
oven write the word flambe and the name
actually refers to the fact this used to
be cooked in a fire and it was that
intense heat that caramelized the bacon
soften the onions and proves that
beautifully brown crispy crust so in
order to simulate that in a home oven we
needed to give all these ingredients a
head start but anyway we'll go ahead and
spread over our fromage blanc mixture
followed by are now room temperature
onions and we will attempt to distribute
those fairly evenly over the top and for
something like this the rule of thumb
for how much to put on
is that we go until we start to have
trouble figuring out where to put the
next one so when you have to start
pausing you figure out where they should
be placed you probably have enough and
then once the onions are set we'll go
ahead and finish up with our bacon and
by the way regarding authenticity I'm
probably putting down three to four
times the amount of bacon you normally
get but it's fine I'm an American so
we'll go ahead and scatter over as much
bacon as we think reasonable at which
point this is ready to finish by
crisping up in a very hot oven or under
a broiler which is how I did it and I'll
cover in the blog post all your options
for cooking this about 5 to 10 minutes
in a very very very hot oven or under
the broiler should do it this is we
already brown the bottom of our crust
all we're really worrying about is
cooking and crisping the top so this is
what mine look like after about 5 or 6
minutes under the broiler as you can see
our bacon is caramelized perfectly and
the edges of our crust is beautifully
browned and one side you know you got
your crust thin enough did you see how
its kind of curling up around the edge
kind of lifting up from the pan that was
done with the proper thinness in fact
let me lift this up and do a
freeze-frame we can see how beautifully
browned it is and it's so thin the
light's coming through so long story
short we nailed it at this point we go
ahead and cut that in quarters and I
will serve that up on my traditional
Alsatian platter and then for a little
bit of color I'm going to add one sprig
of thyme for each slice and since that
is not traditional I'm gonna leave it
whole so someone wants it they can pick
those leaves off or if not they can just
pull that off in California we call that
empowering our guests and I do like the
time but for the sake of time I'm going
to pull that off and start eating and
that my friends is one of the most
delicious things you'll ever eat right
we have smoky caramelized bacon sitting
on top of sweet soft onions which are
nestled into that creamy tangy cheesy
mixture all being moved to our face with
that beautiful crispy crust and did I
mention these are perfect for a party
since we can make a whole bunch of those
tart crust ahead of time and then top
them and just pop them under the broiler
or in the oven when we're ready to serve
but regardless whether for a large group
or small group just an absolutely
fantastic bite of food but anyway that's
it my take on tart flambe
despite the sort of funny name and the
fact you're going to spend half your
party explaining to guess why this is
not called pizza I really do hope you
give this a try soon so head over to
food wishes calm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
[Music]
